item.title: Listen to a conversation about Pixel Watch 4’s new hardware, inside and out.

review.headline_rewrite: Listen to a conversation about Pixel Watch 4’s new hardware, inside and out.
bullets: In the latest Made by Google podcast episode, host Rachid Finge dives deep into our newest wearable, Pixel Watch 4, with product lead Francis Hoe.

Rachid and Francis walk through the watch’s many firsts, including:
- A domed Actua 360 display that’s bigger than ever before (all the better to see Material 3 Expressive!)
- A longer-lasting, faster-charging battery with a new side-charging system
- A serviceable design with a replaceable battery and display
- Standalone emergency satellite communications
- Improved health and fitness tracking
- Raise to Talk with Gemini, right from your wrist
- Accessory bands in a bunch of new colors and materials
The end result is a completely redesigned watch inside and out, as Francis explains: “It's something that's really personal to you in how it looks, how it feels and what it does.”
Listen to the full conversation on Apple Podcasts or Spotify, or watch below.

item.title: The tech antitrust renaissance may already be over

review.headline_rewrite: The tech antitrust renaissance may already be over
bullets:
Around six years ago, a new rallying cry rippled through Washington: “Break Up Big Tech.”
The tech antitrust renaissance may already be over
Google’s search monopoly ruling shows courts might not be willing to break up tech giants.
It was a slogan emblazoned on campaign posters, uttered at congressional hearings, and beginning, it seemed, to echo through the halls of the nation’s antitrust enforcers.
Momentum in the legislatures eventually petered out, but the enforcers at the Justice Department and Federal Trade Commission remained more active than ever.

Elizabeth Warren (D-MA) or Bernie Sanders (I-VT) adopted, but nevertheless, when he became president in 2021, he tapped Lina Khan — who’d first made a name for herself as a law student laying out an antitrust case against Amazon in The Yale Law Journal — to head up the Federal Trade Commission.
A slew of legal complaints against Google, Meta, Amazon, and Apple, threatening to dissolve their alleged monopolies (some first brought under Donald Trump’s administration), began to pile up.
In the last year, the US government seemed to be on something of a winning streak, clinching victories in not one, but two of its landmark antitrust cases against Google.

item.title: iPhone 17, the ‘thinnest iPhone ever,’ and everything else we’re expecting out of Apple’s hardware event

review.headline_rewrite: iPhone 17, the ‘thinnest iPhone ever,’ and everything else we’re expecting out of Apple’s hardware event
bullets: The company is expected to release its iPhone 17 lineup, along with updates for the Apple Watch and AirPods.

As always, there are many rumors circulating, including bigger screens and improved cameras for the iPhone 17 models and the introduction of an ultra-thin iPhone Air that could replace the Plus model.
It’s also rumored to have a 24-megapixel front camera.
Where the MagSafe charger is, the Apple logo is said to be centered for aesthetic reasons.

item.title: Threads challenges X by offering free support for up to 10K characters, plus prominent links

review.headline_rewrite: Threads challenges X by offering free support for up to 10K characters, plus prominent links
bullets: However, X in 2023 introduced a way for its paid subscribers to post up to 25,000 characters, in the hopes of encouraging creators to publish their content directly on its platform.
Seeing this trend, X tried to capitalize on the demand for a longer character count by making it a paid feature.
Threads, however, is making its additional characters available for free.

item.title: Microsoft open-sources Bill Gates’ 6502 BASIC from 1978

review.headline_rewrite: Microsoft open-sources Bill Gates’ 6502 BASIC from 1978
bullets: The company posted 6,955 lines of assembly language code to GitHub under an MIT license, allowing anyone to freely use, modify, and distribute the code that helped launch the personal computer revolution.

"I put the WAIT command in."
At just 6,955 lines of assembly language—Microsoft's low-level 6502 code talked almost directly to the processor.
The MOS 6502 processor that ran this BASIC cost about $25, while competitors charged $200 for similar chips.

Designer Chuck Peddle created the 6502 specifically to bring computing to the masses, and manufacturers built variations of the chip into the Atari 2600, Nintendo Entertainment System, and millions of Commodore computers.
Had Microsoft negotiated a per-unit licensing fee like they did with later products, the deal could have generated tens of millions in revenue.

The version Microsoft released—labeled 1.1—contains bug fixes that Commodore engineer John Feagans and Gates jointly implemented in 1978 when Feagans traveled to Microsoft's Bellevue, Washington, offices.

item.title: You can now attach 10,000 character blogs to your Threads posts

review.headline_rewrite: You can now attach 10,000 character blogs to your Threads posts
bullets: Starting today, Meta is rolling out a tool that lets you attach up to 10,000 characters of text to Threads posts, giving you a way to build upon the 500-character text limit already available when making a post.
On your feed, a text attachment appears as a small block below your main post.

If you include a link in your main Threads post, that link will also be shown in the expanded text attachment, meaning the tool could be a useful way to share a preview of an article or a blog post and then direct readers to the full thing.
